name: GJ 4276
scenarioDescription:
The GJ 4276 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 4276 is a star with 0.41 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.41 times its radius. It is located 69.63 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 6.9 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

GJ 4276 is known to have 1 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 4276 system


GJ 4276 b

GJ 4276 b was discovered by the Calar Alto Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 4276 b is 16.57734 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 4276 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 4276, which contains 1 planets and was discovered by Calar Alto Observatory.
